newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian crude off, Oman drifts, Indo grades weak.
newsitem.headline: Asian crude off, Oman drifts, Indo grades weak.

text.p: Asian crude prices were lower on Monday, and differentials seemed to be following a similar track as Oman edged down.
A European major sold a cargo of Oman to a Japanese refinery at MPM -5 cents and in exchange bought Lower Zakum at ADNOC +7 cents.
The Oman side of the deal was almost matched by another European major selling a cargo of Oman to a U.S. major at MPM -4 cents.
The U.S. major is normally a seller of Oman, but said it wanted the Oman for its own system.
However, it did not discount the possibility of selling the Oman should it see a price advantage later in the month.
Previous deals have been done at discounts of two or three cents. One early deal was even done at a three-cent premium.
The regional market remained equally soft, with a U.S. major buying a Widuri at 20 cents under its ICP -- a further reflection of the weakness of the Minas grade.
Traders said Minas buyers and sellers were at a stand off, with sellers holding out for flat, while buyers were looking for a discount of 20 to 30 cents.
The last deal done was -15 cents, traders said.
Traders said further details of West African imports were emerging.
They said 900,000 barrels of Bonny Light could be combined with Pennington for delivery by a western trader into Japan.
A VLCC of Cabinda was heard sold into China by a trader for April 15-17 loading. A trader said that would indicate China has now bought three VLCCs of April loading Cabinda.
